awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of Raman Spectrometer to Enable Nanoscale Multi-disciplinary Research and Education in Advanced Materials, Health and Energy
awd_abstract_narration:
Raman spectroscopy enables researchers to identify the composition and characterization of nanomaterials. This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award will support the acquisition of a Raman confocal microscope to support new cutting-edge nanotechnology research at California State University (CSU), Chico, spurring research and educational activities in the fields of engineering, materials, energy, computer science, and medicine and benefitting more than 600 students. These research activities could enable societal benefits -- ranging from high-strength, efficient, and smart materials to targeted drug delivery systems. The acquisition of a Raman confocal microscope will enable the development of coursework introducing undergraduate students, many of whom come from underrepresented groups, to cutting-edge technological fields. The microscope will also enable cross-disciplinary collaborations, enhance CSU, Chico's collaborations with City University of New York and Sandia National Laboratory and may promote new partnerships with other research institutions and with industry.  These interactions enhance CSU, Chico's research capabilities and give students an opportunity to work with researchers in other institutions. 

Raman spectroscopy allows the chemical composition of materials to be determined non-destructively by analyzing their atomic level response to a laser via Stokes and anti-Stokes scattering and it is the gold standard for material characterization in a wide range of scientific fields. CSU, Chico faculty will use the instrumentation to advance fundamental research on the synthesis and characterization of nanoparticles, the design of DNA nanostructures, the synthesis and characterization of metal-organic graphene analogues, the fabrication and characterization of nanoscale semiconductor materials, devices, and nanosensors, scaffold development for tissue engineering, and in characterization of plant-based enzymes.  For example, to enable breakthroughs in qualification and process control in AM/3D printing processes of polymer-nanoparticle composite materials, the researchers will analyze geometry flaws, external and internal defects, porosity at the micro- and nano-meter level and the texture of inside and outside surfaces to develop information for enhanced modeling of AM printing processes. Researchers will use XRD and XCT scans to measure the lattice structure, analyze the defects inside nanoparticle-polymer composite materials and predict where a lattice-structure may become distorted or break during printing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project created a lab at California State University Chico (CSU, Chico), College of Engineering, Computer Science and Construction Management (ECC) to enable additional resources and infrastructures for faculty and student research and teaching. The project provided the necessary equipment for creating the Raman Spectroscopy Lab. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the lab was established in the College of ECC but was additionally used by the students and faculty of the College of Natural Sciences (NS). The use of the equipment has been slow during the pandemic but is expected to increase as we adapt to post-pandemic life. The equipment that was purchased and installed to establish the lab included an Raman spectrometer, optical table, and several sampling accessories. 

Students in Integrated Chemistry Laboratory (CHEM381), Materials Science and Engineering (MECH 210), Materials Science and Engineering Laboratory (MECH 210L), and Nanoscale Science and Engineering (MECH 430) utilized the equipment for Raman spectroscopic training and data collection. Therefore, approximately 308 students were familiarized with the equipment in the Department of Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering and Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry. Since the installation of the equipment, two research projects and four classes have directly benefited from the equipment. Two undergraduate students from Department of Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering and two undergraduate students from the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry have used the equipment for three research projects. Some of the projects that were enabled by this equipment and engaged undergraduate students are listed below:

  1. Mechanical properties of silica nanoparticle embedded scaffold
  2. Correlate Raman peak area ratios to presence of defects in metal-organic graphene analogues
  3. Determine the presence of guest molecules coordinated to metal-organic framework host via Raman shifts

The preliminary results of the research and use of the equipment in research are disseminated in the following ways:

Oral Presentations:

  1. Leon, J.*; Fischel, G.*, 36th CSU, Chico Annual Student Research Competition, March 2022. The students gave an oral presentation and won 3rd place in the competition. 
  2. Yasar, O.; Leon, J.*; Fischer, G.*; Yasar, O. Characterizing Mechanical Properties of PEGDA-Silica Hydrogels for Bone Wound Healing, Material Research Society, MRS, Annual Meeting May 2022, Honolulu, Hawaii.
  3. Dr. So's invited talk at Stanford Linear Accelerator Center (SLAC): “Programmable Nanosponges for Next-Generation Solar Energy Conversion Technologies”. 
  4. The students involved in the research via two oral seminars held at CSU, Chico through the Chemistry Summer Research Institute
  5. In October 2022, Dr. Yasar will give a talk about her research at EDXCHICO 2022, which will be streamed live. 
  6. Dr. So and her lab were interviewed through the National Public Radio affiliate's Blue Dot podcast here.

Publications:

  1. Yasar, O.; Leon, J.*; Fischer, G.*; Yasar, O. "Characterizing Mechanical Properties of PEGDA-Silica Hydrogels for Bone Wound Healing". (In-preparation to be submitted to Nanotechnology Journal.
  2. Yoon, S.*; Talin, A. A.; Stavila, V.; Mroz, A. M.; Bennett, T. D.; He, Y.; Keen, D.A.; Hendon, C. H.;  Allendorf, M. D.; So, M. C. "From n- to p‑Type Material: Effect of Metal Ion on Charge Transport in Metal−Organic Materials." ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces. 2021, 13(44), 52055–52062. 

As we transition into more in-person labs, additional courses in Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Department of Physics, and College of Agriculture will benefit from the lab. Approximately 308 students from the departments within the colleges of ECC and NS will use the Raman spectrometer and/or analyze data collected by this system per academic year. CSU, Chico students who include significant numbers of students who are first generation, underrepresented minorities, veterans, and are from other nontraditional and underserved populations, will gain exposure to a state-of-the-art characterization system and sharpen skills to design experiments, collect data, and analyze spectra.


Last Modified: 03/19/2022
Modified by: Monica So

Image
  • Raman confocal microscope system that was installed at the CSU Chico College of ECC. The equipment was acquired by NSF MRI Award #1920332
    Monica C. So
    Public Domain
    Monica So
    Raman confocal microscope system acquired by NSF MRI Award
